name: Krakow Old Town
fun_fact: Fun fact: Every hour, a live trumpeter plays a five-note melody from St. Mary's Basilica tower that abruptly stops mid-tune - commemorating a 1240 trumpeter who sounded the alarm about Mongol invaders but was shot through the throat with an arrow before finishing the call.

hero_dishes.name: Pierogi
hero_dishes.description: Boiled dumplings filled with potato-cheese (ruskie), meat, sauerkraut-mushroom, or sweet fillings like berries - served with butter, fried onions, or sour cream
hero_dishes.origin_story: Poland's national dish dates back to the 13th century, though legend says Saint Hyacinth fed the starving with pierogi during a famine. Each Polish grandmother has her secret recipe passed down through generations. The name comes from Old East Slavic 'pir' (feast) - pierogi were celebration food that became everyday comfort.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Sowiaska Uczta in Kazimierz (locals say best in city, feels like home cooking), Gocinna Chata (full traditional experience with folk decor), U Babci Maliny (budget-friendly, two locations: ul. Szpitalna 38 or ul. Sawkowska 17), or Przystanek Pierogarnia (open until 4AM for late-night cravings)

hero_dishes.name: Zapiekanka
hero_dishes.description: Polish open-faced baguette pizza topped with saut茅ed mushrooms, melted cheese, and doused with ketchup - Krakow's iconic street food
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in communist Poland during the 1970s when ingredients were scarce and Western fast food was forbidden. Zapiekanka was Poland's answer to pizza - made with available ingredients like mushrooms, bread, and processed cheese. After communism fell, it survived because it's delicious. Plac Nowy became zapiekanka central.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Endzior at Plac Nowy in Kazimierz (most popular with locals), Okrglak (round building, former kosher slaughterhouse), or any of the 90% zapiekanka stalls at Plac Nowy Food Market - Zapiexa recommended for creative toppings

hero_dishes.name: Kiebasa (Polish Sausage)
hero_dishes.description: Grilled pork sausage seasoned with garlic and marjoram, served on a baguette with mustard and pickles
hero_dishes.origin_story: Every region of Poland has its sausage, but Krakow's street kiebasa culture is legendary. For over 25 years, two old boys in white smocks have grilled sausages from their blue Nysa van outside Kazimierz using a wood-fired stove - it's become a pilgrimage site for locals.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Krakow Blue Van (Kielbaski pod Hala Targowa) - blue Nysa van on edge of Kazimierz, open every evening except Sundays for 25+ years, or Judah Food Market

hero_dishes.name: 呕urek
hero_dishes.description: Sour rye soup with smoked sausage, hard-boiled egg, and potatoes - served in a hollowed-out bread bowl
hero_dishes.origin_story: This medieval soup was peasant food - fermented rye flour creates the signature sour tang. Originally eaten during Lent and Easter, it became year-round comfort food. The bread bowl (not always used) was practical: eat the soup, then eat the bowl soaked in broth. No dishes to wash.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gocinna Chata (traditional Lesser Poland version), milk bars (communist-era cafeterias with cheap authentic food), or Ogniem i Mieczem for upscale 17th-century recipes

signature_drinks.name: 呕ubr贸wka Vodka
signature_drinks.description: Bison grass vodka with a blade of grass in each bottle - pale yellow-green color with subtle herbal, vanilla notes
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Poles drink 呕ubr贸wka chilled in small shots or mixed with apple juice (called 'Tatanka' or 'szarlotka' - apple pie). The bison grass comes from Biaowie偶a Forest where European bison roam. Locals claim it has aphrodisiac properties - convenient excuse for drinking more.

signature_drinks.name: Kompot
signature_drinks.description: Traditional fruit drink made by simmering dried or fresh fruits (plums, apples, berries) with sugar - served warm or cold
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Every Polish grandmother makes kompot - it's nostalgic comfort in a glass. Served at family dinners alongside pierogi and cabbage rolls. In summer it's cold and refreshing, in winter it's warm and soothing. Milk bars serve it cheap. The fruit at the bottom is a bonus snack.

food_culture_notes: Milk bars (bar mleczny) are communist-era holdovers serving authentic Polish food at incredibly cheap prices - locals still eat there daily
Plac Nowy in Kazimierz transforms from flea market by day to zapiekanka heaven by night
Wierzynek Restaurant in Main Market Square (since 1364) is Poland's oldest continuously operating restaurant
Students make up nearly 30% of Krakow's population (200,000 of 700,000) creating vibrant nightlife and cheap eating spots open until 4AM

landmarks: Main Market Square - Europe's largest medieval plaza at 40,000 square meters
St. Mary's Basilica with hourly trumpet call from tower
Wawel Royal Castle and Cathedral with 13-tonne Sigismund Bell (requires 12 people to ring)
Dragon's Den under Wawel Hill with fire-breathing dragon sculpture
atmosphere: First UNESCO World Heritage Site in the world (1978)
Only major Polish city not destroyed in WWII - medieval architecture intact
200,000 students creating Poland's best party city
Six synagogues in Kazimierz (Jewish Quarter) where Schindler's List was filmed
colors: cobblestone grey in Old Town squares
vibrant market stall colors in Cloth Hall
unique_modern: Jagiellonian University founded 1364 - where Copernicus studied
Feeding pigeons is illegal in Krakow
Dragon legend: city founded when King Krakus defeated a dragon - sculpture breathes real fire
Touching Sigismund Bell supposedly brings love luck
